title: 115_hr6989
content: Restricting federal assistance benefits to verified citizens. Restriction on Federal assistance benefits eligibility based on citizenship requirement. The citizenship requirement for eligibility for Federal assistance programs includes benefits furnished under grants or contracts, but excludes entities receiving grants or contracts for purposes other than providing assistance. The citizenship requirement for Federal assistance benefits includes meeting the attestation and verification requirements. The citizenship verification requirement for Federal assistance benefits involves submitting a written declaration confirming U.S. citizenship or nationality under penalty of perjury. In connection with an application for Federal assistance benefits, individuals must provide satisfactory documentary evidence of United States citizenship or nationality. In connection with a Federal assistance benefits application, individuals must provide proof of US citizenship or nationality, along with a photographic identity document and social security account number. In connection with a Federal assistance benefits application, individuals must provide proof of US citizenship or nationality, along with a photographic identity document and social security account number. The name, number, and citizenship status must be confirmed to match records maintained by the Commissioner of Social Security or the Secretary of Homeland Security. In the case of a recipient of Federal assistance benefits, the individual must provide documentary evidence and information to confirm their name, social security account number, social security number, and citizenship or nationality status. The individual must provide name, social security number, and citizenship for confirmation through the Social Security Administration. The individual must submit their name and social security number to the Commissioner of Social Security for confirmation. Upon receipt, the Commissioner will compare the information with their records and provide either a confirmation or nonconfirmation to the entity. The entity must submit a name, social security number, and other identity information to the Commissioner of Social Security for validation. The Commissioner will confirm if the number is valid and if the individual is a US citizen or national. The entity may also transmit the information to the Department of Homeland Security for further confirmation. The entity must submit identifying information, including name and number, to the Secretary of Homeland Security for confirmation. Upon receipt, DHS will review and confirm the information provided. Nonconfirmation by DHS: The Secretary of Homeland Security will provide either a confirmation or nonconfirmation to an entity regarding the individual's citizenship or nationality based on DHS records. Verification can also be done through the SAVE program. An entity receiving identity information must verify noncitizenship status through the SAVE Program. Individuals without required documentation must be notified. Entities processing applications for federal assistance benefits must notify individuals of their ineligibility if they do not provide required documentation or receive confirmation of citizenship. Individuals have the opportunity to appeal the determination of ineligibility. The head of the department oversees the appeals process. The appeals process allows individuals to challenge a determination of ineligibility for federal assistance benefits. The term "national" refers to a U.S. citizen as defined in the Immigration and Nationality Act. The term "national" in the context of federal assistance benefits refers to a U.S. citizen as defined in the Immigration and Nationality Act. Certain families and households may qualify for benefits based on the eligibility of a child or a parent/legal guardian meeting citizenship requirements. The eligibility for federal assistance benefits is based on the citizenship status of a child's guardian or a family member. If a member of the household meets the citizenship requirement, the entire household is considered eligible, with exceptions for specific programs like supportive housing for the elderly. For housing assistance under section 202 of the Housing Act of 1959 or section 811 of the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act, the citizenship requirement must be met by a household member. The citizenship requirement for housing assistance under the Affordable Housing Act must be met by a disabled individual who is a member of the household. Once the requirement is satisfied for a Federal assistance benefit, the individual will continue to meet the requirement as long as they remain eligible for the benefit. The Director of the Office of General Administration oversees the administration. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may issue regulations and guidance for the declaration of citizenship form and verification process within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may issue regulations and guidance for the citizenship form and verification process based on specific criteria outlined in the Act. The provisions of this section supersede any laws related to eligibility for Federal assistance benefits based on citizenship, nationality, or immigration status, unless determined more restrictive by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Office of Management and Budget determines if the law is more restrictive than this section. If an entity repeatedly provides Federal assistance to ineligible individuals or fails to submit required information, they may be disqualified. If an entity repeatedly fails to submit required information for a Federal assistance program, they will be disqualified and added to the List of Excluded Individuals/Entities until the benefit is recovered. Inspectors general will monitor compliance with the program. The agency overseeing a Federal assistance program must provide regular compliance reports for entities providing benefits under the program. The term "Federal assistance program" includes any provision of Federal law authorizing benefits based on the income or resources of the beneficiary, excluding tax laws. The new legislation applies to determinations of eligibility for Federal assistance programs, including Social Security benefits, based on income or resources. It sets an effective date for implementation and a transition rule for citizenship requirements.
